nodes.text: Individual teacher quality has a substantial causal impact on elementary students' standardized reading and math test achievement; using panel data and teacher fixed effects permits credible estimation of this impact

Method: Construct panel dataset linking students and teachers in two contiguous New Jersey elementary districts across 1989-1990 to 2000-2001 with nationally standardized reading and math subtest scores (NCE scale), student demographics, teacher identifiers and teacher characteristics

Method: Estimate linear models of student test scores including student fixed effects, teacher fixed effects, school-year effects, controls for time-varying student and classroom variables, and a cubic function of teacher experience with a ten-year experience cutoff for identification

Assumption: Identification requires (a) teachers observed with multiple classrooms over years so teacher fixed effects are separable from classroom effects, (b) experience effects are zero after a cutoff (ten years) to separate year from experience, and (c) grade normalization removes grade effects

Evidence: Data plausibly satisfy random-like classroom assignment — tests show current classroom dummies do not predict past test scores and dissimilarity indices of year-to-year teammate mixing are similar to random assignment

Result: Teacher fixed effects are jointly highly significant predictors of student achievement in all four subtests (vocabulary, reading comprehension, math computation, math concepts) with p-values < 0.001

Result: Magnitude — one standard deviation increase in estimated teacher quality raises nationally standardized reading scores by ~0.20 SD and math scores by ~0.24 SD; interquartile teacher differences correspond to about 5.5 NCE (reading) and 6.5 NCE (math)

Result: Teaching experience effects controlling for teacher fixed effects: significant positive effects on reading (vocabulary and comprehension ~4 NCE points or ~0.2 SD over ten years) but little or inconsistent positive effects on math subtests
Claim: Omitting teacher fixed effects biases estimated returns to experience — naive cross-teacher comparisons substantially reduce or remove estimated experience gains (especially for vocabulary)

Result/Evidence: Classroom-level controls (class size, classmates' prior average score, split-level indicators) are not significant predictors of individual test scores in these districts once fixed effects are included

Result: Correlation across subjects — teacher fixed effects are positively correlated across subtests (correlations range ~0.16 to 0.67), indicating many teachers perform consistently across subjects though correlations are lower between vocabulary and other subjects

Result: Variance decomposition bounds — teacher fixed effects and experience account for a modest share of total test variance in these districts (upper bounds ~5.0-6.4%, lower bounds ~1.1-2.8%), but correspond to ~4-23% of policy-relevant variance after accounting for measurement error and student fixed effects

Conclusion: Policies aimed at improving student achievement should prioritize identifying and raising measurable teacher performance rather than relying solely on common observable credentials, since credentials (e.g., masters) are not strongly predictive while measured teacher effects are sizable

Limitation: External validity constraints — analysis uses two similar New Jersey districts with above-median SES; distribution of teacher quality and magnitudes may differ statewide or nationally and school-year fixed effects may absorb some variation in average teacher quality

Policy implication and open question: Performance-based compensation or evaluation (e.g., linking pay or bonuses to student test gains, principal evaluations) is promising but further research is needed on how to identify, recruit, and retain high-quality teachers given teacher supply constraints and cohort changes
